# Treaty of Tordesillas

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Treaty of Tordesillas  
---  
[![Treaty of
Tordesillas.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Treaty_of_Tordesillas.jpg/220px-
Treaty_of_Tordesillas.jpg)](/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Tordesillas.jpg) Front page
of the Portuguese-owned treaty  
Created | 7 June 1494 in Tordesillas, Spain  
[Ratified](/wiki/Ratification "Ratification") | 2 July 1494 in Spain  
5 September 1494 in Portugal  
Location | [Archivo General de Indias](/wiki/Archivo_General_de_Indias "Archivo General de Indias") (Spain)  
[Arquivo Nacional da Torre do Tombo](/wiki/Arquivo_Nacional_da_Torre_do_Tombo
"Arquivo Nacional da Torre do Tombo") (Portugal)  
Author(s) | [Pope Alexander VI](/wiki/Pope_Alexander_VI "Pope Alexander VI") (later confirmed and ratified by [Pope Julius II](/wiki/Pope_Julius_II "Pope Julius II") in 1506)[1]  
Signatories | [Ferdinand II of Aragon](/wiki/Ferdinand_II_of_Aragon "Ferdinand II of Aragon")  
[Isabella I of Castile](/wiki/Isabella_I_of_Castile "Isabella I of Castile")  
[John, Prince of Asturias](/wiki/John,_Prince_of_Asturias "John, Prince of
Asturias")  
[John II of Portugal](/wiki/John_II_of_Portugal "John II of Portugal")[2]  
Purpose | To divide trading and colonising rights for all newly discovered lands of the world located between Portugal and Castile (later applied between the Spanish Crown and Portugal) to the exclusion of other European nations.  
  
The **Treaty of Tordesillas** ([Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language
"Portuguese language"): _Tratado de Tordesilhas_ [[tɾɐˈtaðu ðɨ
tuɾðɨˈziʎɐʃ]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese "Help:IPA/Portuguese"),[3]
[Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"): _Tratado de Tordesillas_
[[tɾaˈtaðo ðe toɾðeˈsiʎas]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish")),
signed at [Tordesillas](/wiki/Tordesillas "Tordesillas") on June 7, 1494, and
authenticated at [Setúbal](/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal "Setúbal"), Portugal, divided
the newly discovered lands outside Europe between the [Portuguese
Empire](/wiki/Portuguese_Empire "Portuguese Empire") and the [Crown of
Castile](/wiki/Crown_of_Castile "Crown of Castile"), along a
[meridian](/wiki/Meridian_\(geography\) "Meridian \(geography\)") 370
[leagues](/wiki/League_\(unit\) "League \(unit\)")[note 1] west of the [Cape
Verde](/wiki/Portuguese_Cape_Verde "Portuguese Cape Verde") islands, off the
west coast of Africa. This line of demarcation was about halfway between the
Cape Verde islands (already Portuguese) and the islands entered by
[Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher Columbus") on
his first voyage (claimed for Castile and León), named in the treaty as
[Cipangu](/wiki/Names_of_Japan "Names of Japan") and [Antilia](/wiki/Antilia
"Antilia") (Cuba and [Hispaniola](/wiki/Hispaniola "Hispaniola")).

The lands to the east would belong to Portugal and the lands to the west to
Castile. The treaty was signed by Spain, 2 July 1494 and by Portugal, 5
September 1494. The other side of the world was divided a few decades later by
the [Treaty of Zaragoza](/wiki/Treaty_of_Zaragoza "Treaty of Zaragoza"),
signed on 22 April 1529, which specified the antimeridian to the line of
demarcation specified in the Treaty of Tordesillas. Originals of both treaties
are kept at the [Archivo General de Indias](/wiki/Archivo_General_de_Indias
"Archivo General de Indias") in Spain and at the [Arquivo Nacional da Torre do
Tombo](/wiki/Arquivo_Nacional_da_Torre_do_Tombo "Arquivo Nacional da Torre do
Tombo") in Portugal.[8]

This treaty would be observed fairly well by Spain and Portugal, despite
considerable ignorance as to the geography of the New World; however, it
omitted all of the other European powers. Those countries generally ignored
the treaty, particularly those that became Protestant after the [Protestant
Reformation](/wiki/Protestant_Reformation "Protestant Reformation").

## Signing and
enforcement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Tordesillas&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Signing and enforcement")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Spain_and_Portugal.png/400px-
Spain_and_Portugal.png)](/wiki/File:Spain_and_Portugal.png)

[](/wiki/File:Spain_and_Portugal.png "Enlarge")

Lines dividing the non-Christian world between Castile and Portugal: the 1494
Tordesillas meridian (purple) and the 1529 Zaragoza antimeridian (green)

The Treaty of Tordesillas was intended to solve the dispute that had been
created following the return of Christopher Columbus and his crew, who had
sailed for the Crown of Castile. On his way back to Spain he first reached
Lisbon, in Portugal. There he asked for another meeting with [King John
II](/wiki/John_II_of_Portugal "John II of Portugal") to show him the newly
discovered lands.

After learning of the Castilian-sponsored voyage, the Portuguese King sent a
threatening letter to the [Catholic Monarchs](/wiki/Catholic_Monarchs
"Catholic Monarchs") stating that by the [Treaty of
Alcáçovas](/wiki/Treaty_of_Alc%C3%A1%C3%A7ovas "Treaty of Alcáçovas") signed
in 1479 and confirmed in 1481 with the [papal bull](/wiki/Papal_bull "Papal
bull") _[Æterni regis](/wiki/%C3%86terni_regis "Æterni regis")_ , that granted
all lands south of the [Canary Islands](/wiki/Canary_Islands "Canary Islands")
to Portugal, all of the lands discovered by Columbus belonged, in fact, to
Portugal. Also, the Portuguese King stated that he was already making
arrangements for a fleet (an armada led by [Francisco de
Almeida](/wiki/Francisco_de_Almeida "Francisco de Almeida")) to depart shortly
and take possession of the new lands.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] After
reading the letter the Catholic Monarchs knew they did not have any military
power in the Atlantic to match the Portuguese, so they pursued a diplomatic
way out.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] On 4 May 1493 [Pope Alexander
VI](/wiki/Pope_Alexander_VI "Pope Alexander VI") ([Rodrigo
Borgia](/wiki/Rodrigo_Borgia "Rodrigo Borgia")), an
[Aragonese](/wiki/Crown_of_Aragon "Crown of Aragon") from
[Valencia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Valencia "Kingdom of Valencia") by birth, decreed
in the bull _[Inter caetera](/wiki/Inter_caetera "Inter caetera")_ that all
lands west and south of a pole-to-pole line 100 leagues west and south of any
of the islands of the [Azores](/wiki/Azores "Azores") or the Cape Verde
Islands should belong to Castile, although territory under Catholic rule as of
Christmas 1492 would remain untouched.[9] The bull did not mention Portugal or
its lands, so Portugal could not claim newly discovered lands even if they
were east of the line. Another bull, _[Dudum siquidem](/wiki/Dudum_siquidem
"Dudum siquidem")_ , entitled _Extension of the Apostolic Grant and Donation
of the Indies_ and dated 25 September 1493, gave all mainlands and islands,
"at one time or even still belonging to India" to Spain, even if east of the
line.[10]

The Portuguese King John II was not pleased with that arrangement, feeling
that it gave him far too little land—it prevented him from possessing India,
his near term goal.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] By 1493 Portuguese explorers had reached the
southern tip of Africa, the [Cape of Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape
of Good Hope"). The Portuguese were unlikely to go to war over the islands
encountered by Columbus, but the explicit mention of India was a major issue.
As the Pope had not made changes, the Portuguese king opened direct
negotiations with the Catholic Monarchs, King
[Ferdinand](/wiki/Ferdinand_II_of_Aragon "Ferdinand II of Aragon") and Queen
[Isabella](/wiki/Isabella_I_of_Castile "Isabella I of Castile"), to move the
line to the west and allow him to claim newly discovered lands east of the
line. In the bargain, John accepted _[Inter caetera](/wiki/Inter_caetera
"Inter caetera")_ as the starting point of discussion with Ferdinand and
Isabella, but had the boundary line moved 270 leagues west, protecting the
Portuguese route down the coast of Africa and giving the Portuguese rights to
lands that now constitute the Eastern quarter of Brazil. As one scholar
assessed the results, "both sides must have known that so vague a boundary
could not be accurately fixed, and each thought that the other was deceived,
[concluding that it was a] diplomatic triumph for Portugal, confirming to the
Portuguese not only the true route to India, but most of the South
Atlantic".[11]

The treaty effectively countered the bulls of Alexander VI but was
subsequently sanctioned by [Pope Julius II](/wiki/Pope_Julius_II "Pope Julius
II") by means of the bull _Ea quae pro bono pacis_ of 24 January 1506.[12]
Even though the treaty was negotiated without consulting the Pope, a few
sources call the resulting line the "Papal Line of Demarcation".[13]

Very little of the newly divided area had actually been seen by Europeans, as
it was only divided via the treaty. Castile gained lands including most of the
Americas, which in 1494 had little proven wealth. The easternmost part of
current Brazil was granted to Portugal when in 1500 [Pedro Álvares
Cabral](/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral "Pedro Álvares Cabral") landed there
while he was en route to India. Some historians contend that the Portuguese
already knew of the South American bulge that makes up most of Brazil before
this time, so his landing in Brazil was not an accident.[14] One scholar
points to Cabral's landing on the Brazilian coast 12 degrees farther south
than the expected [Cape São Roque](/wiki/Cape_S%C3%A3o_Roque "Cape São
Roque"), such that "the likelihood of making such a landfall as a result of
freak weather or navigational error was remote; and it is highly probable that
Cabral had been instructed to investigate a coast whose existence was not
merely suspected, but already known".[15]

The line was not strictly enforced—the Spanish did not resist the [Portuguese
expansion of Brazil](/wiki/Portuguese_colonization_of_the_Americas "Portuguese
colonization of the Americas") across the meridian. However, the Catholic
Monarchs attempted to stop the Portuguese advance in Asia, by claiming the
meridian line ran around the world, dividing the whole world in half rather
than just the Atlantic. Portugal pushed back, seeking another papal
pronouncement that limited the line of demarcation to the Atlantic. This was
given by Pope [Leo X](/wiki/Leo_X "Leo X"), who was friendly toward Portugal
and its discoveries, in 1514 in the bull _Praecelsae devotionis_.[16]

For a period between 1580 and 1640, the treaty was rendered meaningless, as
the Spanish King was also King of Portugal. It was superseded by the [1750
Treaty of Madrid](/wiki/Treaty_of_Madrid_\(13_January_1750\) "Treaty of Madrid
\(13 January 1750\)") which granted Portugal control of the lands it occupied
in South America. However, the latter treaty was immediately repudiated by the
Catholic Monarch. The [First Treaty of San
Ildefonso](/wiki/First_Treaty_of_San_Ildefonso "First Treaty of San
Ildefonso") settled the problem, with Spain acquiring territories east of the
[Uruguay River](/wiki/Uruguay_River "Uruguay River") and Portugal acquiring
territories in the [Amazon Basin](/wiki/Amazon_Basin "Amazon Basin"). Emerging
Protestant maritime powers, particularly England and The Netherlands, and
other third parties such as Roman Catholic France, did not recognize the
division of the world between only two Roman Catholic nations brokered by the
pope.[17]

## Tordesillas
meridian[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Tordesillas&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Tordesillas meridian")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Early_Tordesillas_lines.jpg/330px-
Early_Tordesillas_lines.jpg)](/wiki/File:Early_Tordesillas_lines.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Early_Tordesillas_lines.jpg "Enlarge")

Early Tordesillas lines in South America (1495–1545)

The Treaty of Tordesillas only specified the line of demarcation in leagues
from the Cape Verde Islands. It did not specify the line in degrees, nor did
it identify the specific island or the specific length of its league. Instead,
the treaty stated that these matters were to be settled by a joint voyage
which never occurred. The number of degrees can be determined via a ratio of
marine leagues to degrees applied to the Earth regardless of its assumed size,
or via a specific marine league applied to the true size of the Earth, called
"our sphere" by historian [Henry Harrisse](/wiki/Henry_Harrisse "Henry
Harrisse").[18]

  * The earliest Aragonese opinion was provided by Jaime Ferrer in 1495 at the request of the Aragonese king and Castilian queen to those monarchs. He stated that the demarcation line was 18° west of the most central island of the Cape Verde Islands, which is [Fogo](/wiki/Fogo,_Cape_Verde "Fogo, Cape Verde") according to Harrisse, having a longitude of 24°25'W of [Greenwich](/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich "Royal Observatory, Greenwich"), hence Ferrer placed the line at 42°25'W on his sphere, which was 21.1% larger than our sphere. Ferrer also stated that his league contained 32 Olympic [stades](/wiki/Stadion_\(unit_of_length\) "Stadion \(unit of length\)"), or 6.15264 km according to Harrisse, thus Ferrer's line was 2,276.5 km west of Fogo at 47°37'W on our sphere.[19]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/CantinoPlanisphere.png/330px-
CantinoPlanisphere.png)](/wiki/File:CantinoPlanisphere.png)

[](/wiki/File:CantinoPlanisphere.png "Enlarge")

[Cantino planisphere](/wiki/Cantino_planisphere "Cantino planisphere")
depicting the meridian, 1502

  * The earliest surviving Portuguese opinion is on the [Cantino planisphere](/wiki/Cantino_planisphere "Cantino planisphere") of 1502. Because its demarcation line was midway between Cape Saint Roque (northeast cape of South America) and the mouth of the [Amazon River](/wiki/Amazon_River "Amazon River") (its estuary is marked _Todo este mar he de agua doçe—_ "All of this sea is fresh water"—and its river is marked _Rio grande_ , "great river"), Harrisse concluded that the line was at 42°30'W on our sphere. Harrisse believed the large estuary just west of the line on the Cantino map was that of the Rio Maranhão (this estuary is now the [Baía de São Marcos](/wiki/Ba%C3%ADa_de_S%C3%A3o_Marcos "Baía de São Marcos") and the river is now the [Mearim](/wiki/Mearim_River "Mearim River")), whose flow is so weak that its gulf does _not_ contain fresh water.[20]
  * In 1518 another Castilian opinion was provided by Martin Fernandez de Enciso. Harrisse concluded that Enciso placed his line at 47°24'W on his sphere (7.7% smaller than ours), but at 45°38'W on our sphere using Enciso's numerical data. Enciso also described the coastal features near which the line passed in a very confused manner. Harrisse concluded from this description that Enciso's line could also be near the mouth of the Amazon between [49°](/wiki/49th_meridian_west "49th meridian west") and [50°W](/wiki/50th_meridian_west "50th meridian west").[21]
  * In 1524 the Castilian pilots (ships' captains) Thomas Duran, Sebastian Cabot (son of [John Cabot](/wiki/John_Cabot "John Cabot")), and Juan Vespuccius (nephew of [Amerigo Vespucci](/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci "Amerigo Vespucci")) gave their opinion to the Badajoz Junta, whose failure to resolve the dispute led to the Treaty of Saragossa. They specified that the line was 22° plus nearly 9 miles west of the center of [Santo Antão](/wiki/Santo_Ant%C3%A3o,_Cape_Verde "Santo Antão, Cape Verde") (the westernmost Cape Verde island), which Harrisse concluded was 47°17'W on their sphere (3.1% smaller than ours) and 46°36'W on our sphere.[22]
  * In 1524 the Portuguese presented a globe to the Badajoz Junta on which the line was marked 21°30' west of Santo Antão (22°6'36" on our sphere).[23]

## Antimeridian: Moluccas and Treaty of
Zaragoza[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Tordesillas&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Antimeridian: Moluccas and Treaty of Zaragoza")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. ---|---  
  
Main article: [Treaty of Zaragoza](/wiki/Treaty_of_Zaragoza "Treaty of
Zaragoza")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Blaeu_-
_Moluccae_Insulae_Celeberrimae.jpg/220px-Blaeu_-
_Moluccae_Insulae_Celeberrimae.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blaeu_-
_Moluccae_Insulae_Celeberrimae.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Blaeu_-_Moluccae_Insulae_Celeberrimae.jpg "Enlarge")

Dutch map of the Moluccas (north is at right)

Initially, the line of demarcation did not encircle the Earth. Instead, Spain
and Portugal could conquer any new lands they were the first to discover,
Spain to the west and Portugal to the east, even if they passed each other on
the other side of the globe.[24] But Portugal's discovery of the highly valued
[Moluccas](/wiki/Moluccas "Moluccas") in 1512 caused Spain to argue in 1518
that the Treaty of Tordesillas divided the Earth into two equal hemispheres.
After the surviving ships of [Magellan](/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan "Ferdinand
Magellan")'s fleet visited the Moluccas in 1521, Spain claimed that those
islands were within its western hemisphere. In 1523, the [Treaty of
Vitoria](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Vitoria&action=edit&redlink=1 "Treaty of
Vitoria \(page does not exist\)") called for the [Badajoz
Junta](/w/index.php?title=Badajoz_Junta&action=edit&redlink=1 "Badajoz Junta
\(page does not exist\)") to meet in 1524, at which the two countries tried to
reach an agreement on the anti-meridian but failed.[25] They finally agreed in
a treaty signed at [Zaragoza](/wiki/Zaragoza "Zaragoza") that Spain would
relinquish its claims to the Moluccas upon the payment of 350,000
[ducats](/wiki/Ducat "Ducat") (≈100 kg) of gold by Portugal to Spain. To
prevent Spain from encroaching upon Portugal's Moluccas, the anti-meridian was
to be 297.5 leagues or 17° to the east of the Moluccas, passing through the
islands of Las Velas and Santo Thome.[26] This distance is slightly smaller
than the 300 leagues determined by Magellan as the westward distance from los
Ladrones to the Philippine island of [Samar](/wiki/Samar_\(island\) "Samar
\(island\)"), which is just west of due north of the Moluccas.[27]

The Moluccas are a group of islands west of [New Guinea](/wiki/New_Guinea "New
Guinea"). However, unlike the large modern [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesia
"Indonesia") [archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago") of the [Maluku
Islands](/wiki/Maluku_Islands "Maluku Islands"), to 16th-century Europeans the
Moluccas were a small chain of islands, the only place on Earth where
[cloves](/wiki/Clove "Clove") grew, just west of the large north Malukan
island of [Halmahera](/wiki/Halmahera "Halmahera") (called Gilolo at the
time). Cloves were so prized by Europeans for their medicinal uses that they
were worth their weight in gold.[28][29] 16th- and 17th-century maps and
descriptions indicate that the main islands were [Ternate](/wiki/Ternate
"Ternate"), [Tidore](/wiki/Tidore "Tidore"), [Moti](/wiki/Moti_Island "Moti
Island"), [Makian](/wiki/Makian "Makian") and [Bacan](/wiki/Bacan "Bacan"),
although the last was often ignored even though it was by far the largest
island.[30][31][32] The principal island was Ternate at the chain's northern
end (0°47'N, only 11 kilometres (7 mi) in diameter) on whose southwest coast
the Portuguese built a stone fort ([Forte de São João Baptista de
Ternate](/wiki/Fort_Kastela "Fort Kastela")) during 1522–23,[33] which could
only be repaired, not modified, according to the Treaty of Saragossa. This
north-south chain occupies two degrees of [latitude](/wiki/Latitude
"Latitude") bisected by the equator at about 127°24'E, with Ternate, Tidore,
Moti, and Makian north of the equator and Bacan south of it.

Although the treaty's Santo Thome island has not been identified, its "Islas
de las Velas" (Islands of the Sails) appear in a 1585 Spanish history of
China, on the 1594 world map of [Petrus Plancius](/wiki/Petrus_Plancius
"Petrus Plancius"), on an anonymous map of the Moluccas in the 1598 London
edition of [Linschoten](/wiki/Jan_Huyghen_van_Linschoten "Jan Huyghen van
Linschoten"), and on the 1607 world map of Petro Kærio, identified as a north-
south chain of islands in the northwest Pacific, which were also called the
"Islas de los Ladrones" (Islands of the Thieves) during that
period.[34][35][36] Their name was changed by Spain in 1667 to "Islas de las
Marianas" ([Mariana Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana Islands")), which
include [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam") at their southern end. Guam's longitude of
144°45'E is east of the Moluccas' longitude of 127°24'E by 17°21', which is
remarkably close by 16th-century standards to the treaty's 17° east. This
longitude passes through the eastern end of the main north Japanese island of
[Hokkaidō](/wiki/Hokkaid%C5%8D "Hokkaidō") and through the eastern end of New
Guinea, which is where Frédéric Durand placed the demarcation line.[37]
Moriarty and Keistman placed the demarcation line at 147°E by measuring 16.4°
east from the western end of New Guinea (or 17° east of 130°E).[38] Despite
the treaty's clear statement that the demarcation line passes 17° east of the
Moluccas, some sources place the line just east of the Moluccas.[39][40][41]

The Treaty of Saragossa did not modify or clarify the line of demarcation in
the Treaty of Tordesillas, nor did it validate Spain's claim to equal
hemispheres (180° each), so the two lines divided the Earth into unequal
hemispheres. Portugal's portion was roughly 191° whereas Spain's portion was
roughly 169°. Both portions have a large uncertainty of ±4° because of the
wide variation in the opinions regarding the location of the Tordesillas line.

Portugal gained control of all lands and seas west of the Saragossa line,
including all of Asia and its neighboring islands so far "discovered," leaving
Spain most of the [Pacific Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean").
Although the Philippines were not named in the treaty, Spain implicitly
relinquished any claim to them because they were well west of the line.
Nevertheless, by 1542, King [Charles V](/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor
"Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor") decided to colonize the Philippines, judging
that Portugal would not protest because the archipelago had no spices.
Although a number of expeditions sent from [New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New
Spain") arrived in the Philippines, they were unable to establish a settlement
because the return route across the Pacific was unknown. King [Philip
II](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain "Philip II of Spain") succeeded in 1565 when he
sent [Miguel Lopez de Legazpi](/wiki/Miguel_Lopez_de_Legazpi "Miguel Lopez de
Legazpi") and [Andres de Urdaneta](/wiki/Andres_de_Urdaneta "Andres de
Urdaneta"), establishing the initial Spanish trading post at [Cebu](/wiki/Cebu
"Cebu") and later founding [Manila](/wiki/Manila "Manila") in 1571.

Besides [Brazil](/wiki/Colonial_Brazil "Colonial Brazil") and the Moluccas,
Portugal eventually controlled [Angola](/wiki/Portuguese_Angola "Portuguese
Angola"), [Mozambique](/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique "Portuguese Mozambique"),
[Portuguese Guinea](/wiki/Portuguese_Guinea "Portuguese Guinea"), and [São
Tomé and Príncipe](/wiki/Portuguese_S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe
"Portuguese São Tomé and Príncipe") (among other territories and bases) in
[Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa"); several bases or territories as
[Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat, Oman"), [Ormus](/wiki/Ormus "Ormus") and
[Bahrein](/wiki/Bahrein "Bahrein") in the Persian Gulf, [Goa](/wiki/Goa
"Goa"), [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay "Bombay") and [Daman and
Diu](/wiki/Daman_and_Diu "Daman and Diu") (among other coastal cities) in
[India](/wiki/Portuguese_India "Portuguese India");
[Ceylon](/wiki/Portuguese_Ceylon "Portuguese Ceylon"), and
[Malacca](/wiki/Portuguese_Malacca "Portuguese Malacca"), bases in present-day
Indonesia as [Makassar](/wiki/Makassar "Makassar"), [Solor](/wiki/Solor
"Solor") and [Ambon](/wiki/Ambon_Island "Ambon Island"), [Portuguese
Timor](/wiki/Portuguese_Timor "Portuguese Timor"), the _entrepôt_ -base of
[Macau](/wiki/Portuguese_Macau "Portuguese Macau") and the entrepôt-enclave of
[Dejima](/wiki/Dejima "Dejima") ([Nagasaki](/wiki/Nagasaki "Nagasaki")) in the
Far East.

Spain, on the other hand, would control vast western regions in the Americas,
in areas ranging from the present-day United States to present-day Argentina,
an empire that would extend to the Philippines, and bases in Ternate and
[Formosa](/wiki/Formosa "Formosa") (17th century).

## Effect on other European
powers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Tordesillas&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Effect on other European powers")]

The treaty was historically important in dividing Latin America, as well as
establishing Spain in the western Pacific until 1898. However, it quickly
became obsolete in North America, and later in Asia and Africa, where it
affected colonization. It was ignored by other European nations, and with the
decline of Spanish and Portuguese power, the home countries were unable to
hold many of their claims, much less expand them into poorly explored areas.
Thus, with sufficient backing, it became possible for any European state to
colonize open territories, or those weakly held by Lisbon or Madrid. With the
fall of [Malacca](/wiki/Malacca "Malacca") to the Dutch, the VOC ([Dutch East
India Company](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company "Dutch East India Company"))
took control of Portuguese possessions in Indonesia, claiming Western New
Guinea and Western Australia, as [New Holland](/wiki/New_Holland_\(Australia\)
"New Holland \(Australia\)"). Eastern Australia remained in the Spanish half
of the world until claimed for Britain by [James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook "James
Cook") in 1770. The attitude towards the treaty that other governments had was
expressed in a statement attributed to France's King [Francis
I](/wiki/Francis_I_of_France "Francis I of France"), "Show me Adam's
will!"[42]

## The Treaty of
Madrid[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Tordesillas&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: The Treaty of Madrid")]

Main article: [Treaty of Madrid (13 January
1750)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Madrid_\(13_January_1750\) "Treaty of Madrid \(13
January 1750\)")

In January 13, 1750, [King John V of Portugal](/wiki/King_John_V_of_Portugal
"King John V of Portugal") and [Ferdinand VI of
Spain](/wiki/Ferdinand_VI_of_Spain "Ferdinand VI of Spain") signed the Treaty
of Madrid, in which both parts sought to establish the borders between Brazil
and Spanish America, admitting that the Treaty of Tordesillas, as it had been
envisioned in 1494 had been superseded, and was considered void. Spain was
acknowledged sovereignty over the Philippines, while Portugal would get the
territory of the Amazon River basin. Portugal would relinquish the [colony of
Sacramento](/wiki/Colonia_del_Sacramento "Colonia del Sacramento"), on the
northern bank of the [River Plata](/wiki/R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata "Río de la
Plata") in modern-day Uruguay, while getting the territory of the [Seven
Missions](/wiki/Misiones_Orientales "Misiones Orientales").[43]

## Modern
claims[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Tordesillas&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Modern claims")]

The Treaty of Tordesillas was invoked by Chile in the 20th century to defend
the principle of an [Antarctic](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica") sector
extending along a meridian to the [South Pole](/wiki/South_Pole "South Pole"),
as well as the assertion that the treaty made Spanish (or Portuguese) all
undiscovered land south to the Pole.[44]

Indonesia took possession of [Netherlands New
Guinea](/wiki/Netherlands_New_Guinea "Netherlands New Guinea") in 1962,
supporting its claim by stating the Empire of [Majapahit](/wiki/Majapahit
"Majapahit") had included western New Guinea, and that it was part of the
Treaty of Tordesillas.

The Treaty of Tordesillas was also invoked by Argentina in the 20th century as
part of its [claim](/wiki/Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_dispute "Falkland
Islands sovereignty dispute") to the [Falkland/Malvinas
Islands](/wiki/Falkland_Islands "Falkland Islands").[45]

## Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Tordesillas&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** 370 leagues equals 2,193 km, 1,362 statute miles, or 1,184 nautical miles.  
These figures use the _legua náutica_ (nautical league) of four Roman miles
totaling 5.926 km, which was used by Spain during the 15th, 16th, and 17th
centuries for navigation.[4] In 1897 Henry Harrise noted that Jaime Ferrer,
the expert consulted by King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella, stated that a
league was four miles of six [stades](/wiki/Stadion_\(unit_of_length\)
"Stadion \(unit of length\)") each.[5] Modern scholars agree that the
geographic stade was the Roman or Italian stade, not any of several other
Greek stades, supporting these figures.[6][7] Harrise is in the minority when
he uses the stade of 192.27 m marked within the stadium at [Olympia,
Greece](/wiki/Olympia,_Greece "Olympia, Greece"), resulting in a league (32
stades) of 6.153 km, 3.8% larger.
